metadata.case_name: Upper Ganges Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Mohd. Khalilul Rehman and others
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal Nos. 196 of 1952 and 4 of 1959

facts.text: Mukhtiar Ahmed, father of the landlords, granted a theka to the Company corresponding to 1341 F of the lands in dispute for a period of ten years ending with 1350 F (June 1943).
The theka contained a clause giving option to the Company to get it renewed for five years and consequently the theka was renewed for five years from 1351 F to 1355 F (upto June 1948).
In March 1948, the landlords gave notice to the Company to the effect that the theka would not be renewed after 1355 F.
The Company did not agree to hand over possession to the landlords.
Landlords filed suit for ejectment of the Company under the U. P. Tenancy Act, 1939.
Company resisted claiming it was not a thekadar but a tenant and had become hereditary tenant under s. 29 of the U. P. Tenancy Act.
Suit decreed on November 3, 1948.
Company's appeal against the decree failed.
Company's second appeal to the Board of Revenue dismissed on July 22, 1950.
Company remained in possession from November 1948 to July 1950 on account of stay orders.
Execution began in October 1950; possession delivered to landlords on October 13, 1950; Dakhalnama filed on October 15, 1950.
Company offered resistance to actual ejectment, leading to proceedings under s. 145 CrPC; magistrate ordered attachment in November 1950 and appointed two superdars (caretakers).
Company applied to Board for certificate, granted, leading to Civil Appeal No. 196 of 1952.
U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 (U. P. I of 1951) came into force on July 1, 1953.

Company instituted proceedings to recover possession under s. 232 read with ss. 12 and 20; Sub-Divisional Officer decided in favour of Company in January 1954, ordering delivery of possession under both sections.
Landlords' appeal dismissed in January 1955; appellate court held entitled under s. 12 but did not decide under s. 20.
Landlords' second appeal to Board of Revenue dismissed in January 1956; Board decided on s. 12 basis.
Supreme Court granted special leave to landlords in May 1956, leading to Civil Appeal No. 4 of 1959.
Supreme Court heard appeals on November 18, 1959, remanded for finding on s. 20.
Board submitted finding that Company entitled to benefit of s. 20 and acquired Adhivasi rights.
Company recorded as occupant (thekadar) in Khasra or Khatauni of 1356 F.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Company was recorded as occupant of the land in the Khasra or Khatauni of 1356 F in its own right so as to acquire Adhivasi rights under s. 20(b) of the U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950.
Whether the Company is entitled to rights under s. 12 of the Act as a hereditary tenant.

petitioner_arguments.text: Company was in occupation in 1356 F in its own right, not on behalf of court (despite stay orders) or landlords; recorded as occupant entitling to s. 20 Adhivasi rights; also entitled under s. 12 as hereditary tenant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 20(b), s. 12 U. P. Zamindari Abolition Act; s. 29 U. P. Tenancy Act

respondent_arguments.text: Company's possession after November 3, 1948 decree was not in own right but on behalf of court due to stay orders; recorded as thekadar in 1356 F means possession on behalf of landlords.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 20(b) U. P. Zamindari Abolition Act

respondent_arguments.text: Company was not a thekadar in 1356 F as theka expired June 30, 1948 (for s. 12 claim).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s. 12 U. P. Zamindari Abolition Act

court_reasoning.text: Occupant means person in occupation in own right, not on behalf of someone else; Company's possession continued under stay orders in same right as before decree, not on behalf of court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Stay orders do not convert possession to on behalf of court.

court_reasoning.text: Revenue entry as thekadar does not preclude looking at nature of possession; entry continued post-theka expiry without change order; landlords' contradictory positions on thekadar status.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Court can go behind entry to determine if occupation in own right.

court_reasoning.text: Das Gupta J. dissent: Entry as thekadar records possession on behalf of lessor; cannot look beyond record; thekadar equated to farmer of rents under U.P. Tenancy Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Entries show possession as thekadar, not as occupant in own right.

holdings.text: Company entitled to Adhivasi rights under s. 20(b) as recorded as occupant in 1356 F in own right.
No need to decide s. 12 entitlement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Swami Prasad and another v. Board of Revenue, U. P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Occupant means in occupation in own right, not on behalf of someone else.
Receiver case; person in occupation as agent of receiver not own right.
Board decision on stay order possession as on behalf of court; incorrect as applied here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Lala Nanak Chand v. The Board of Revenue, U. P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Recording as occupant sufficient without actual possession proof; not about nature of possession.

statutes_cited.name: U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 (U. P. I of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: Company entitled to Adhivasi rights under s. 20(b) and possession under s. 232; s. 12 for hereditary tenant claim.

statutes_cited.name: U. P. Land Revenue Act, 1901
statutes_cited.relevance: Khasra and Khatauni of 1356 F prepared thereunder for s. 20(b).

statutes_cited.name: United Provinces Tenancy (Amendment) Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Alternative basis for regaining possession under s. 20.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Proceedings due to resistance to ejectment.

outcome.summary: Landlords' appeal No. 4 of 1959 dismissed as Company entitled to s. 20 benefits; Company's appeal No. 196 of 1952 dismissed as infructuous. Parties to bear own costs.
outcome.relief_granted: Company entitled to possession as Adhivasi under s. 20.
outcome.costs: Parties bear their own costs in this Court.

key_quotes.text: "Occupant" ... must ... be given its ordinary dictionary meaning which is a person in occupation ... the person should be in occupation in his own right and not on behalf of someone else.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines key term for s. 20 eligibility.

key_quotes.text: The possession of the Company, though it continued because of the stay orders, cannot be held to be on behalf of the court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument that stay orders make possession benami.

key_quotes.text: The record in the Khasra of possession as a Thekadar appears to me therefore to amount to record of possession on behalf of the Thekadars lessor.
key_quotes.speaker: court
